awd_titl_txt: Development of Charge Transfer Dissociation Mass Spectrometry (CTD-MS) of Oligosaccharides
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Glen Jackson and his group at West Virginia University are developing instruments for the characterization of oligosaccharides - complex sugar molecules critical to living systems.  Specifically, Dr. Jackson is assessing and expanding the usefulness of mass spectrometry as a means of determining the structure of these complex biomolecules.  The research benefits from collaboration and student exchanges with a research team at the French National Institute for Agricultural Research (INRA) in Nantes, France.  The tools being developed help answer important questions about the structure and function of biological molecules including, but not limited to, oligosaccharides.  The new instruments can address, for example, questions about how sugars are digested, the gelling properties of food-grade pectins, and cell recognition pathways in living systems.  The project is also providing a mechanism to educate elementary school students through organization of activity stations at local science fairs.

The Jackson group is developing two mass spectrometers, a 2D and a 3D ion trap, for charge transfer dissociation (CTD) of oligosaccharides.  Initial efforts seek to improve fragmentation efficiency by incorporating additional ion optics in the reactant ion beam.  This modification may also reduce reaction times, enabling CTD to be coupled with ultra-high performance liquid chromatographic separations of complex mixtures.  Instrument variables such as reagent ion kinetic energy, flux, and electron affinity (through the choice of noble gas); CTD reaction time; and the trapping parameter (qz) are optimized to enhance fragmentation behavior.  Key aims are the elucidation of general rules for fragmentation and identification of the best conditions with which to augment oligosaccharide characterization.  Isolated fractions of well-characterized oligosaccharides are used to elucidate the effect of oligosaccharide properties on the extent and nature of fragmentation.  Properties expected to influence glycosidic and cross-ring fragmentation mechanisms include: glycan sequence, inter-residue linkage position, branching point, charge state, adducting ions, and glycan modifications such as esterification, amination and sulfation.  Additional studies investigate the efficacy of CTD towards other oxygenated oligomers, including polymers, PEGylated drugs, anionic surfactants and oligonucleotides.  These combined studies demonstrate the strengths and weaknesses of CTD relative to existing technologies and help guide future research towards high-impact applications.

por.por_cntn:
Complex carbohydrates, or polysaccharides, make up about two thirds of all the biomass on earth and are an important source of carbon-sequestering biomass, food, nutrients, medicine, fuel, and formulation products, like gelling agents. Complex carbohydrates are also crucial components of our cells and tissues; they strengthen our ligaments and tendons, and they allow cells to communicate and detect foreign pathogens. Our understanding of biological and biochemical processes involving polysaccharides therefore depends on our ability to determine the specific, detailed structure of these complex structures.

The goal of our project was to develop a new scientific instrument with the capability to provide detailed structural information about a wide variety of complex saccharides. Our instrument modification was successful, and the capabilities provided by our instrument helped elucidate the chemical structures of complicated, fragile, and especially complex carbohydrates. We collaborated with some of the world?s best experts in carbohydrate chemistry to show that our instrument can be used to distinguished between different polymers of glucose, such as laminarin found in algae and seaweed and cellulose found in plants. These polymers only differ in the linkage position of the glucose monomers, and our technique could correctly identify polysaccharides that contained both types of linkages. We also demonstrated the ability to analyze the detailed structure of complex polysaccharides structures called glycosaminoglycans, which are found in our cell membranes and ligaments. In other published work, we demonstrated the ability to characterize the complex structure of pectin found in certain fruits. Our new instrument can also detect subtle changes in the complicated structures of essential nutrients like Vitamin B12 and macrolide medicines like erythromycin. Our instrument therefore has a wide range of potential applications, and future applications are most likely to impact society in practical ways through the analysis of pharmaceuticals and food additives.

In addition to the scientific findings presented above, our project helped train students and scientists at several universities in the US and at research facilities in France and Germany. The project also provided multiple opportunities to educate elementary school students through the organization of activity stations at local science fairs. The instrument is still functioning as a research and teaching aid at West Virginia University, where we are continuing to deepen our understanding and develop new applications.
